<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate the period of a pendulum. Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 1.1 and Fig. 1.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 114, 761, 355]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[299, 365, 369, 384]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[633, 365, 705, 384]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 396, 593, 415]]<|/det|>
A pendulum has been set up for you as shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 428, 144, 446]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 428, 176, 446]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 428, 920, 462]]<|/det|>
Measure the distance \(l\) between the bottom of the clamp supporting the pendulum and the centre of the pendulum bob.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[559, 473, 918, 492]]<|/det|>
<form>l = .................................................... cm [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 505, 180, 524]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 504, 920, 539]]<|/det|>
Explain briefly how you measured to the centre of the pendulum bob as accurately as possible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 553, 920, 572]]<|/det|>
<form>.......................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[860, 583, 920, 602]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 613, 148, 631]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 613, 680, 632]]<|/det|>
Adjust the length of the pendulum until the distance \(l = 50.0 \text{cm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 644, 920, 677]]<|/det|>
Displace the bob slightly and release it so that it swings. Fig. 1.2 shows one complete oscillation of the pendulum.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 691, 750, 709]]<|/det|>
Measure, and record in Table 1.1, the time \(t\) for 20 complete oscillations.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 722, 920, 755]]<|/det|>
Calculate, and record in Table 1.1, the period \(T\) of the pendulum. The period is the time for one complete oscillation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 768, 574, 787]]<|/det|>
Calculate, and record in Table 1.1, the value of \(T^2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 800, 803, 817]]<|/det|>
Repeat the procedure using \(l\) values of \(60.0 \text{cm}\), \(70.0 \text{cm}\), \(80.0 \text{cm}\) and \(90.0 \text{cm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[490, 42, 508, 58]]<|/det|> <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 72, 541, 88]]<|/det|> Table 1.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 915, 269]]<|/det|>
\(l/\mathrm {cm}\)\(t/\mathrm {s}\)\(T/\mathrm {s}\)\(T^{2}/\mathrm {s}^{2}\)
50.0
60.0
70.0
80.0
90.0
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 268, 917, 286]]<|/det|> [4] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 299, 146, 317]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 299, 920, 333]]<|/det|> Plot a graph of \(T^2 /\mathrm{s}^2\) (y-axis) against \(l / \mathrm{cm}\) (x-axis). Start the \(T^2\) axis at a convenient value close to the minimum value of \(T^2\). <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[250, 344, 740, 688]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 705, 920, 724]]<|/det|> [4] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 736, 148, 755]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 736, 920, 769]]<|/det|> Explain briefly why timing 20 oscillations gives a more accurate result for the period \(T\) than timing 1 oscillation. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 839, 920, 857]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 844, 920, 863]]<|/det|> [Total: 11]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the horizontal distance travelled by a metal ball after it rolls off the end of a plastic track. Fig. 4.1 shows the set-up.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 119, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
The ball rolls down a plastic track. The left-hand side of the track is fixed. The right-hand side can be adjusted so that the ball comes off the track at different angles.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 165, 920, 198]]<|/det|>
The student measures the horizontal distance that the ball travels from the right-hand end of the track to the point that it hits the floor.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 211, 920, 244]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment to investigate how the horizontal distance travelled by the metal ball depends on the angle that the right-hand end of the track makes with the bench.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 257, 473, 274]]<|/det|>
You are **not** required to do this experiment.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[91, 285, 907, 485]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 500, 532, 518]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 4.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 530, 537, 548]]<|/det|>
The following apparatus is available to the student:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 562, 428, 579]]<|/det|>
· track with stand, boss and clamp

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 577, 351, 593]]<|/det|>
· selection of metal balls.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 607, 740, 625]]<|/det|>
Other apparatus normally available in a school laboratory can also be used.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 640, 324, 656]]<|/det|>
In your plan, you should:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 670, 465, 687]]<|/det|>
· list any additional apparatus required

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 685, 920, 717]]<|/det|>
· explain briefly how you would do the investigation, including the measurements you would take

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 717, 507, 734]]<|/det|>
· state the key variables to be kept constant

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 732, 920, 764]]<|/det|>
· draw a suitable table, with column headings, to show how you would display your readings (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 763, 655, 780]]<|/det|>
· explain how you would use the results to reach a conclusion.
